docs.title: Program Overview
docs.text:
This platform provides a structured, self-paced learning path for aspiring security engineers. Each week, new topics will be published, guiding students through fundamental and advanced cybersecurity concepts. The goal is to encourage independent learning through hands-on practice and research using various online resources such as: - Google - ChatGPT - YouTube - Blogs & Technical Articles - Practical Exercises & Projects

By practicing through this program, you will be equipped with a strong foundation in various aspects of security and develop the skills necessary to thrive in this fast-paced industry. You will also gain fundamental skills applicable across multiple security domains.

docs.title: 📌 Weekly Learning Objectives
docs.text:
• Each week, a set of cybersecurity topics will be provided.
  • Topics will cover theoretical foundations, practical exercises, and real-world applications.

docs.title: 🔍 Independent Research & Practice (7 Days)
docs.text: Students are encouraged to explore and learn through: - 🔹 Google searches - 🔹 YouTube tutorials - 🔹 Blogs and technical articles - 🔹 ChatGPT for explanations - 🔹 Hands-on exercises and personal projects

docs.title: 📊 Assessment & Progression
docs.text:
• To evaluate progress, students can conduct self-assessments or peer discussions based on the topics covered.
  • If a structured evaluation is needed, students may arrange for a quick on-call interview or guidance from a security professional.

docs.title: Key Guidelines
docs.text:
✅ All content and learning paths are free and structured for self-paced learning. ✅ Practical exercises and projects are essential for reinforcing theoretical knowledge.

"Time is money, and balancing professional and personal life is crucial. Take charge of your own learning, practice consistently, and grow at your own pace. However, structured evaluations can be invaluable."

📩 If you require a quick on-call interview or guidance from a security professional, please contact via LinkedIn.

docs.title: Level 1: Web Development & Python Basics
docs.text:
Description: This level focuses on building a strong foundation in web development and Python programming. By practicing these fundamental concepts, students will be able to: - Create structured and visually appealing websites using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. - Develop a responsive portfolio website with modern design principles. - Gain hands-on experience with Python basics, scripting, and data processing. - Prepare for more advanced topics, including cybersecurity, by understanding the core functionalities of web technologies and programming.

Topics Covered: - Web Development Fundamentals (HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Bootstrap, Media Queries) - Responsive Web Design & Portfolio Building - Python Basics: Data Types, Functions, OOP, and Scripting - Python Libraries & Web Scraping - Hosting and Deploying Projects

View Detailed Program

docs.title: Level 2: Linux & Shell Scripting
docs.text:
Description: This level introduces students to Linux system administration and shell scripting. By practicing these concepts, students will: - Gain hands-on experience with Linux commands and system management. - Learn to navigate the Linux filesystem and manage processes effectively. - Understand security permissions and user management. - Develop automation skills using shell scripting.

View Detailed Program

docs.title: Level 3: Basics of Cybersecurity
docs.text:
Description: This level provides a foundational understanding of cybersecurity concepts, security threats, and practical tools used in the field. By completing this level, students will: - Learn key security principles, such as the CIA Triad and security vulnerabilities. - Understand cybersecurity threats, including malware, DoS attacks, and OSINT techniques. - Gain hands-on experience with threat intelligence tools and cybersecurity best practices. - Prepare for advanced security topics and career opportunities in cybersecurity.

View Detailed Program

docs.title: Level 4: Networking & Network Security
docs.text:
Description: This level focuses on networking fundamentals and network security concepts relevant to cybersecurity. Students will: - Learn networking protocols, addressing schemes, and network security technologies. - Understand network devices, encryption, and intrusion detection/prevention systems. - Gain hands-on experience with network monitoring, analysis, and defense strategies. - Develop practical skills for securing networks and mitigating threats.

View Detailed Program

docs.title: Level 5: Cryptography
docs.text:
Description: This three-week program provides a deep dive into cryptographic principles, algorithms, and applications. Participants will explore key cryptographic concepts, encryption techniques, hashing methods, and real-world security implementations. The program emphasizes hands-on learning using widely adopted cryptographic tools and techniques.

Topics Covered: - Cryptographic Fundamentals (Symmetric & Asymmetric Encryption, Classical Ciphers, Key Distribution) - Modern Cryptographic Principles (HTTPS, TLS, Certificate Authorities) - Encryption Techniques & Hashing (AES, RSA, MD5, SHA-256, Digital Signatures) - Cryptanalysis & Security Attacks (Brute Force, Rainbow Table, Birthday Attack) - Secure Communication & Key Management (Diffie-Hellman, Blockchain & Cryptography) - Cryptographic Compliance & Standards (FIPS, NIST, GDPR Encryption Policies)

View Detailed Program

docs.title: Level 6: Security Automation and Advanced Topics
docs.text: Description: This one-week program focuses on automating security tasks using Python. Students will develop practical skills in network simulation, data analysis, and file integrity monitoring with Jira API integration.

docs.title: Topics Covered:
docs.text:
• Day 1-2: Network Simulation and Scripting with Python
  • Socket programming, network scanning, log analysis.
  • Day 3-4: Data Analysis and Visualization with Pandas and Matplotlib
  • Security data analysis, trend identification, visualization.
  • Day 5-7: File Integrity Monitoring and Incident Reporting with Jira API
  • File hash monitoring, API integration for automated incident reporting.

📌 View Detailed Program

docs.title: Level 7: SOC Training
docs.text: Description: This eight-week program is designed to equip participants with the knowledge and skills necessary to operate effectively in a Security Operations Center (SOC). Students will learn incident response, threat detection, and SOC architecture through hands-on tasks and research.

docs.title: Topics Covered:
docs.text:
• Week 1: Introduction to SOC
  • SOC levels, procedures, ticketing systems, and incident workflows.
  • Week 2: SOC Tools and Technologies
  • SIEM, SOAR, EDR, XDR, threat intelligence, log integration.
  • Week 3: Hands-on Incident Investigation
  • Investigating real-world security incidents.
  • Week 4: WebStrike Blue Team Lab
  • Log analysis, security detection rules, YARA & Sigma rules.
  • Week 5: TryHackMe Rooms
  • Hands-on SOC challenges on TryHackMe.
  • Week 6: Configuring ELK Stack
  • Setting up ELK stack and integrating security logs.
  • Week 7: SOC Challenges
  • WebStrike, QRadar, Pyramid of Pain, Wazuh SIEM.
  • Week 8: SOC Architecture & SOAR Playbooks
  • Building a SOC environment, integrating security tools, creating a SOAR playbook.

📌 View Detailed Program

docs.text: Description: This one-week program introduces students to the fundamentals of modern web applications and protocols. Through a combination of theoretical learning and practical exercises, participants will gain insights into web technologies, HTTP protocols, and web application architecture.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: This one-week intensive program provides foundational knowledge and hands-on skills in Linux system management and shell scripting. Participants will learn essential Linux commands, system monitoring techniques, security configurations, log file management, and automation through scripting. The program culminates in a hands-on project to develop a system monitoring and maintenance script.

docs.title: Task 1: Understanding the Linux Directory Structure
docs.text:
Objective: Gain familiarity with Linux file system and key directories.

🔹 Research and document the purpose of key directories such as /bin, /etc, /home, /var, /usr, and /tmp. 🔹 Navigate the Linux file system using commands like ls, cd, pwd, and tree.

docs.title: Task 2: Essential Linux Commands
docs.text:
Objective: Learn and practice essential Linux commands for file manipulation and process management.

🔹 Compile a list of frequently used Linux commands (e.g., cp, mv, rm, touch, grep, find, chmod, chown, ps, kill, tar, zip, unzip). 🔹 Execute and document the behavior of these commands with different arguments and options.

docs.title: Task 3: Understanding and Managing Path Variables
docs.text:
Objective: Learn about the Linux PATH variable and its role in command execution.

🔹 Explain the significance of PATH. 🔹 View and modify path variables using commands like echo $PATH and export PATH.

docs.title: Task 4: System Monitoring and Resource Management
docs.text:
Objective: Utilize Linux commands to monitor and manage system performance.

🔹 Practice using commands like top, htop, df, du, free, uptime, and vmstat. 🔹 Document the purpose, usage, and output of each command.

docs.title: Task 5: Network Management Commands
docs.text:
Objective: Learn and apply essential Linux networking commands.

🔹 Use commands like ifconfig, ip, ping, netstat, ss, traceroute, and nmap to troubleshoot and manage network connections. 🔹 Document findings and analyze network behaviors.

docs.title: Task 6: Security & Permissions in Linux
docs.text:
Objective: Understand and manage file permissions and security measures.

🔹 Learn how to use chmod, chown, and chgrp. 🔹 Explore user, group, and other permission concepts. 🔹 Implement basic security measures and document the process.

docs.title: Task 7: Log Files and System Logs
docs.text:
Objective: Analyze system logs and track system activity.

🔹 Identify key log files in /var/log (e.g., syslog, auth.log, dmesg). 🔹 Use tail, less, cat, and grep to analyze logs.

docs.title: Task 8: Basics of Shell Scripting
docs.text:
Objective: Write simple shell scripts to automate tasks.

🔹 Understand the structure of a shell script. 🔹 Write and execute basic scripts involving variables, loops, and conditional statements.

docs.title: Project: System Monitoring and Maintenance Script
Objective: Develop a script to automate system monitoring and maintenance tasks.
docs.text:
📌 Tasks: - Disk Usage Monitoring: Alert when disk usage exceeds a threshold. - CPU & Memory Monitoring: Log CPU and memory utilization. - Top Processes: List the top 5 memory-consuming processes. - System Updates: Check for available updates. - Backup: Automate file backup to a designated location.

📌 Deliverables: - Script Documentation: Explain commands and logic used. - Screenshots & Outputs: Demonstrate script execution. - Analysis Report: Summarize findings and improvements.

docs.title: Bonus Challenge: OverTheWire Bandit (Levels 0-14)
docs.text:
Objective: Strengthen Linux command-line skills through real-world challenges.

🔹 Solve Bandit challenges at OverTheWire (https://overthewire.org/wargames/bandit/). 🔹 Document solutions and key learnings for each level (0-14).

docs.title: Additional Research Topics
docs.text: 📌 Process Management: Understanding ps, kill, nice, and jobs. 📌 User Management: Managing users and groups (useradd, passwd, groupadd). 📌 Package Management: Using apt, yum, and dnf. 📌 Crontab & Scheduling: Automating tasks with cron jobs. 📌 Firewall & Security: Configuring iptables and ufw.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: This three-week program provides a comprehensive introduction to cybersecurity concepts. Participants will explore fundamental principles, security threats, and practical tools used in the field. Through structured tasks, real-world examples, and hands-on exercises, students will gain a solid foundation in cybersecurity, preparing them for more advanced studies or roles in the industry.

docs.title: Task 1: Introduction to Information Security
docs.text: 🔹 Objective: Understand the basics of information security. 🔹 To Do: Research and summarize the importance of information security.

docs.title: Task 2: CIA Triad
docs.text: 🔹 Objective: Learn about the CIA (Confidentiality, Integrity, Availability) triad. 🔹 To Do: Provide real-world examples of each aspect of the CIA triad.

docs.title: Task 3: Key Security Concepts
docs.text: 🔹 Objective: Understand key security terms like threats, vulnerabilities, exploits, and payloads. 🔹 To Do: Submit a report explaining each concept with real-world examples.

docs.title: Task 4: CVE and CWE
docs.text: 🔹 Objective: Learn about Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) and Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE). 🔹 To Do: Research and summarize recent CVEs and CWEs, explaining their security impact.

docs.title: Task 5: VPN, Proxy, and Tor
docs.text: 🔹 Objective: Compare VPNs, proxies, and Tor for online privacy. 🔹 To Do: Submit a comparison including use cases and limitations.

docs.title: Task 6: Surface Web, Deep Web, and Dark Web
docs.text: 🔹 Objective: Understand the differences between them. 🔹 To Do: Provide a detailed explanation of their characteristics and uses.

docs.title: Task 7: Virtualization Setup
docs.text: 🔹 Objective: Install and configure a virtual environment for security testing. 🔹 To Do: Install VMware/VirtualBox, set up Kali Linux, and document the process with screenshots.

docs.title: Task 8: Malicious Software
docs.text: 🔹 Objective: Learn about different types of malware (viruses, worms, keyloggers, trojans, rootkits, etc.). 🔹 To Do: Submit a report analyzing each type with examples.

docs.title: Task 9: DoS and DDoS
docs.text: 🔹 Objective: Understand Denial of Service (DoS) and Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks. 🔹 To Do: Provide case studies on major attacks and their impact.

docs.title: Task 10: VirusTotal and AlienVault OTX
docs.text: 🔹 Objective: Use VirusTotal and AlienVault OTX for threat intelligence. 🔹 To Do: Submit a report on their functionality and applications in cybersecurity.

docs.title: Task 11: Internet and DNS Functionality
docs.text: 🔹 Objective: Learn how the internet and DNS work. 🔹 To Do: Explain the process when visiting a website and how search engines index the web.

docs.title: Week 3: Advanced Security Concepts and OSINT
Task 12: Introduction to OSINT
docs.text: 🔹 Objective: Understand Open Source Intelligence (OSINT) methodologies. 🔹 To Do: Research and report on OSINT tools like Maltego, Google Dorks, OSINT Framework, and Shodan.

docs.title: Task 13: OSINT Project
docs.text: 🔹 Objective: Conduct an OSINT project using learned tools. 🔹 To Do: Submit findings with documentation.

docs.title: Task 14: Recent Malware and Security Threats
docs.text: 🔹 Objective: Analyze recent malware incidents and security threats. 🔹 To Do: Submit a technical write-up on real-world cybersecurity incidents.

docs.title: Task 15: Technical Write-Up on Log4j and Stuxnet
docs.text: 🔹 Objective: Research and document the Log4j and Stuxnet vulnerabilities. 🔹 To Do: Submit detailed technical reports.

docs.title: Task 16: Firewall Technologies
docs.text: 🔹 Objective: Compare traditional firewalls, next-gen firewalls, and web application firewalls. 🔹 To Do: Submit a report on their differences and use cases.

docs.title: Task 17: Network Fundamentals
docs.text: 🔹 Objective: Understand LAN, MAN, WAN, and their roles in cybersecurity. 🔹 To Do: Submit a summary of each type and their practical applications.

docs.title: Task 18: Identity and Access Management (IAM) & Privileged Access Management (PAM)
docs.text: 🔹 Objective: Learn the importance of IAM and PAM. 🔹 To Do: Submit a report showcasing their use and security benefits.

docs.title: Additional Exercises
docs.text:
✅ OverTheWire Bandit Challenge (Levels 0-14) - Mandatory - OverTheWire: Bandit

✅ Suggested Hands-On Labs & Articles - Introduction to Cybersecurity on Medium - Understanding the CIA Triad - Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) Guide - Setting Up a Cybersecurity Lab - Exploring OSINT Techniques - Malware Analysis and Case Studies

docs.title: Outcome & Expectations
docs.text:
By completing this program, students will: ✅ Develop a strong foundation in cybersecurity. ✅ Understand common security threats and defense mechanisms. ✅ Gain hands-on experience with cybersecurity tools. ✅ Be prepared for more advanced security topics.

docs.title: Networking and Network Security - 3 Week Program
Description
docs.text: This three-week program is designed to provide participants with a comprehensive understanding of networking fundamentals and network security concepts relevant to cybersecurity. Through a series of structured tasks, students will explore networking protocols, devices, addressing schemes, security technologies, threat detection, and defense strategies. The program emphasizes hands-on learning using free solutions and tools available online.

docs.title: Week 1: Foundations of Networking and Network Security
Objective: Understand the OSI and TCP/IP models and the functions of each layer.
docs.text:
• Study the OSI and TCP/IP models and create a comparative analysis.
  • Research and summarize the differences between connection-oriented (TCP) and connectionless (UDP) protocols.

docs.title: Objective: Explore TCP/IP suite protocols and common application layer protocols.
docs.text:
• Create a detailed guide on TCP/IP suite protocols (TCP, UDP, IP, ICMP).
  • Investigate and document the purpose and usage scenarios of common application layer protocols like HTTP, HTTPS, DNS, and FTP.

docs.title: Objective: Explore network devices and their security perspectives.
docs.text:
• Investigate the functionalities of routers, switches, hubs, and their roles in network security.
  • Compare and contrast the security implications of each network device.

docs.title: Week 2: Advanced Networking Concepts and Security Technologies
Objective: Study IP addressing, subnetting, CIDR notation, and MAC addresses.
docs.text:
• Explore IPv4 and IPv6 addressing schemes, subnetting, and CIDR notation.
  • Investigate MAC addresses, ARP, and MAC address spoofing.

docs.title: Objective: Research encryption protocols, intrusion detection/prevention systems (IDS/IPS).
docs.text:
• Research SSL/TLS, IPsec encryption protocols, and their strengths/weaknesses.
  • Investigate different IDS/IPS solutions, their features, and deployment considerations.

docs.title: Objective: Explore ISP, VPN, proxies, and their roles in network privacy and security.
docs.text:
• Understand the concepts of ISP, VPN, and proxies.
  • Explore their roles in network privacy, security, and anonymity.

docs.title: Week 3: Network Monitoring, Threats, and Defense
Objective: Conduct network traffic analysis and analyze network logs for security threats.
docs.text:
• Use Wireshark or similar tools to analyze network traffic for anomalous behavior.
  • Analyze network logs and events to detect and investigate security incidents.
  • Complete this challenge and create a report: Poisoned Credentials Challenge

docs.title: Objective: Research common network threats and vulnerabilities.
docs.text:
• Compile a list of common network threats (malware, DDoS, phishing) and vulnerabilities.
  • Identify and document network misconfigurations that could be exploited by attackers.

docs.title: Objective: Develop network defense strategies and incident response plans.
docs.text:
• Develop a network defense strategy incorporating firewalls, IDS/IPS, and other security mechanisms.
  • Create an incident response plan outlining procedures for detecting, responding to, and recovering from network security incidents.

docs.title: Objective: Implement network security measures based on the learned concepts and strategies.
docs.text:
• Implement firewall rules to restrict network traffic.
  • Deploy an open-source IDS/IPS solution for threat detection.
  • Document the implementation process, including configurations and rationale.

docs.title: Articles
docs.text:
• Networking Fundamentals - Cisco
  • How VPNs Work
  • Firewall Technologies Explained

docs.title: Videos
docs.text:
• OSI Model Explained
  • Wireshark for Beginners
  • Cyber Security Threats & How to Mitigate Them

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
• Each task should be thoroughly researched and documented.
  • Utilize free online resources and tools for practical exercises.
  • Submit detailed reports for each task, including findings, analyses, and implementations.
  • Practical exercises and labs must include screenshots and step-by-step explanations.

By completing the tasks and project, students will gain hands-on experience and develop skills applicable to real-world networking and security scenarios.

docs.title: Task 3: Modern Cryptographic Principles
docs.text:

docs.title: Task 5: Symmetric and Asymmetric Encryption

docs.title: Task 6: Hashing Algorithms
docs.text:

docs.title: Task 7: Digital Signatures & Certificates

docs.title: Task 9: Secure Communication & Key Management

docs.title: Task 10: Blockchain & Cryptography

docs.title: Task 11: Implementing Cryptography in Real-World Applications

  • Learn about end-to-end encryption in messaging apps (Signal, WhatsApp).

docs.title: Task 12: Cryptographic Compliance & Standards

docs.title: Level 6: Security Automation and Advanced Topics
One-Week Program: Security Automation and Advanced Topics
docs.text: This program provides hands-on experience in security automation using Python. Participants will learn to automate network tasks, analyze security data, and implement file integrity monitoring with incident reporting.

docs.title: Day 1-2: Network Simulation and Scripting with Python
Task 1: Network Simulation and Scripting with Python
docs.text: Objective: Use Python to simulate network tasks and automate related processes.

docs.title: Activities:
docs.text:
• Socket Programming: Write Python scripts to simulate client-server communication using sockets.
  • Network Scanning: Create scripts to scan a range of IP addresses and identify active hosts using the scapy library.
  • Log Analysis: Simulate network log files and write scripts to parse and analyze these logs.

📖 Reference Articles: - Python for Network Automation - Introduction to Scapy

docs.title: Day 3-4: Data Analysis and Visualization with Pandas and Matplotlib
Task 2: Data Analysis and Visualization with Pandas and Matplotlib
docs.text: Objective: Analyze and visualize security-related data using Pandas and Matplotlib.

docs.title: Activities:
docs.text:
• Install and set up Pandas and Matplotlib.
  • Use Pandas to clean and preprocess security data.
  • Create visualizations with Matplotlib to identify trends and patterns in the data.
  • Develop a complete data analysis project using a sample security dataset.

📖 Reference Articles: - Data Analysis in Cybersecurity - Visualizing Security Logs

docs.title: Day 5-7: File Integrity Monitoring and Incident Reporting with Jira API
Task 3: File Integrity Monitoring and Incident Reporting with Jira API
docs.text: Objective: Develop a Python script to monitor file integrity changes in a folder and automatically create a Jira ticket for detected incidents.

docs.title: Activities:
docs.text:
• Implement a script to calculate and store hash values (MD5 or SHA256) of files in a specified folder.
  • Set up the script to run periodically (e.g., every hour) to compare current file hash values with previously stored values.
  • Configure the script to detect changes in file integrity (hash values) and trigger an alert or action.
  • Integrate the script with the Jira API to automatically create an incident ticket when file integrity changes are detected.
  • Test the script to ensure proper functionality, including API integration and incident ticket creation.

📖 Reference Articles: - File Integrity Monitoring with Python - Automating Incident Reporting with Jira API

docs.title: Final Submission Guidelines
docs.text:
Complete each task within the designated days, focusing on understanding concepts and practical application.

  • Utilize online resources, documentation, and practical exercises to enhance learning and understanding.
  • Submit reports, scripts, and project deliverables as instructed, including documentation and explanations where necessary.
  • Aim for clarity, efficiency, and reliability in all Python scripts and projects.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: This 8-week SOC (Security Operations Center) training program is designed to equip participants with the knowledge and skills necessary to operate effectively within a SOC environment. Through a combination of theoretical learning and hands-on practical exercises, students will explore various aspects of SOC operations, including incident response, tool usage, threat detection, and architecture design. Each week focuses on specific topics and tasks, building upon the previous week's learning objectives.

docs.title: Tasks:
docs.text:
1. Introduction to SOC

  2. Research and understand the role and importance of a Security Operations Center (SOC).

  3. SOC Levels and Procedures

  4. Differentiate roles and responsibilities of SOC L1, L2, and L3.

  5. Learn Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for each level.

  6. Ticketing System

  7. Overview of ticketing systems and their importance in SOC operations.

  8. Incident Workflows

  9. Study the processes for handling and resolving security incidents.

  10. General Terminologies

  11. Research and compile a list of key SOC terminologies.

  12. Incident Analysis and Response

  13. Understand the six stages of the incident response plan:
    • Preparation
    • Identification
    • Containment
    • Eradication
    • Recovery
    • Lessons Learned

📌 Reference: - Understanding SOC Operations

docs.title: Tasks:
docs.text:
1. Study Various Incidents

  2. Research different types of security incidents and how they are handled.

  3. Incident Response Stages

  4. Apply the six incident response stages to different security incidents.

  5. SOC Process for Incident Analysis and Closure

  6. Learn and describe the steps for analyzing and closing incidents.

  7. Common Security Attacks Report

    • Research and report on 10 common security attacks in organizations.
    • Explain the SOC team’s response at each stage of incident response.

  8. Overview of SOC Tools

    • Research and summarize the functions of:
    • SIEM (Security Information and Event Management)
    • SOAR (Security Orchestration, Automation, and Response)
    • EDR (Endpoint Detection and Response)
    • XDR (Extended Detection and Response)

  9. Data Loss Prevention (DLP) Solutions

    • Understand and explain:
    • Enterprise DLP (EDLP)
    • Network DLP (NDLP)
    • Email DLP

  10. Threat Intelligence & Syslog Server

    • Explain the use of threat intelligence feeds and syslog servers.

  11. Log Integration in SIEM

    • Learn and document the process of integrating logs into SIEM.

  12. Rule Creation in SIEM

    • Study and practice creating and tuning rules in SIEM.

📌 References: - SIEM Basics and Rule Creation - Understanding Threat Intelligence Feeds

docs.title: Tasks:
docs.text:
1. Incident Investigation
    • Perform at least 10 incident investigations using LetsDefend.io or similar platforms.

📌 Reference: - How to Investigate Security Incidents

docs.title: Tasks:
docs.text:
1. Fraud Attack Investigations Using Application Logs

    • Research and document fraud investigation techniques using application logs.

  2. Identify Common Log Sources

    • List 10 log sources used for detecting security attacks (Cloud, AD, Web, Infra, etc.).

  3. SIEM Security Detection Rules

    • Write 20 different SIEM detection rule logics.

  4. Log Integration Methodologies

    • Research log integration using syslog.

  5. YARA & Sigma Rules

    • Research and document YARA & Sigma rules and their use in threat detection.

📌 Reference: - Creating Effective SIEM Rules

docs.title: Tasks:
docs.text:
1. Complete various TryHackMe SOC-related rooms

📌 Reference: - TryHackMe SOC Learning Path

docs.title: Tasks:
docs.text:
1. Set up ELK Stack (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana)

  2. Integrate a Log Source in ELK SIEM

    • Create two security attack detection rules.

📌 Reference: - ELK Stack Setup Guide

docs.title: Tasks:
docs.text:
1. Complete the following challenges:

    • WebStrike Challenge
    • QRadar 101

  2. TryHackMe Challenges:

    • Pyramid of Pain
    • Unified Kill Chain
    • Wazuh SIEM
    • Phishing Emails

📌 Reference: - SOC Challenges and Learning Paths

docs.title: Tasks:
docs.text:
1. Create a SOAR Playbook

    • Use Shuffle SOAR or another SOAR platform.

  2. Design & Build a SOC Architecture

    • Implement security tools (SIEM, SOAR, IDS, IPS, EDR, DLP).
    • Simulate attacks and assess detection capabilities.

📌 Reference: - Building an Effective SOC

docs.title: Final Instructions
docs.text:
• This syllabus is designed to provide a comprehensive understanding of SOC operations within two months.
  • Engage in self-research and practical exercises.
  • Use online resources, documentation, and labs to complete each task.
  • Submit detailed reports summarizing research, configurations, and experiences.
  • Ensure practical exercises include screenshots and step-by-step explanations.

This structured training will provide hands-on experience and deep knowledge in SOC operations, making you ready for SOC Analyst roles in the industry. 🚀

docs.title: Modern Web Applications and Protocol Basics
Overview
docs.text: By the end of this week, students will understand the basics of modern web applications and protocols. They will learn about various web technologies, HTTP protocols, and web application architecture. Practical tasks will reinforce theoretical knowledge and provide hands-on experience.

docs.title: Task 1: Understanding the Web
docs.text: Objective: Learn the fundamentals of the web. - Concepts: WWW, HTTP, URL, Website, WebServer, and Web Browser. - Research and write a brief summary explaining each term. 📖 Reference Articles: - How the Web Works - Introduction to HTTP

docs.title: Task 2: Basics of Browser and Developer Tools
docs.text: Objective: Get familiar with web browsers and their developer tools. - Explore Chrome DevTools, inspect elements, view console logs, and network activity. 📖 Reference Articles: - Chrome DevTools Guide - Firefox Developer Tools

docs.title: Task 3: Client-Side Languages and Concepts
docs.text: Objective: Understand client-side technologies. - Learn HTML, CSS, and JavaScript basics. - Create a simple webpage using these technologies. 📖 Reference Articles: - HTML & CSS Basics - JavaScript Introduction

docs.title: Task 4: Server-Side Concepts and Web Servers
docs.text: Objective: Learn about server-side technologies and web servers. - Introduction to Node.js, PHP, Python for server-side programming. - Overview of web servers like Apache and Nginx. 📖 Reference Articles: - Introduction to Node.js - How Web Servers Work

docs.title: Task 5: HTTP Protocols
docs.text: Objective: Understand HTTP protocols and their components. - HTTP request methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE). - HTTP response codes (1xx, 2xx, 3xx, 4xx, 5xx). - HTTP headers, security policies, access control, authentication, and cookies. 📖 Reference Articles: - Understanding HTTP Requests - HTTP Status Codes

docs.title: Task 6: HTTPS vs HTTP, HSTS
docs.text: Objective: Learn the difference between HTTP and HTTPS. - Understand the importance of HTTPS and how HSTS (HTTP Strict Transport Security) works. - Write a report on the benefits of HTTPS over HTTP. 📖 Reference Articles: - Why Use HTTPS - How HSTS Works

docs.title: Task 7: Data Storage - Database Servers
docs.text: Objective: Learn about different types of databases. - SQL databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL) vs NoSQL databases (MongoDB, Cassandra). - Practical Task: Set up a simple database and perform CRUD operations. 📖 Reference Articles: - SQL vs NoSQL Databases - Beginner’s Guide to Databases

docs.title: Task 8: Web Application Architecture
docs.text: Objective: Understand different web application architectures. - Monolithic Architecture, Single Page Applications (SPA), Microservices. - Write a report comparing these architectures. 📖 Reference Articles: - Microservices vs Monolithic - How Single Page Applications Work

docs.title: Task 9: Serverless Architecture and Containers vs VMs
docs.text: Objective: Learn about serverless computing and the difference between containers and virtual machines. - Overview of AWS Lambda, Google Cloud Functions. - Compare Docker containers with VMs. 📖 Reference Articles: - What is Serverless Computing? - Containers vs VMs

docs.title: Task 10: Intercepting Requests and Responses
docs.text: Objective: Use Burp Suite to intercept HTTP traffic. - Intercept requests and responses from two websites. - Take screenshots and explain HTTP headers. 📖 Reference Articles: - Burp Suite Guide

docs.title: Task 11: OWASP Top 10 (2013-2021)
docs.text: Objective: Learn about the OWASP Top 10 web application security risks. - Study each of the top 10 risks and mitigation strategies. 📖 Reference Articles: - OWASP Top 10 (Latest)

docs.title: Task 12: Basics of Reconnaissance
docs.text: Objective: Perform reconnaissance on a network. - Domain reconnaissance, WHOIS lookup, DNS reconnaissance. - Identify live hosts, open ports, running services using tools like Nmap. 📖 Reference Articles: - Introduction to Reconnaissance

docs.title: Additional Practical Tasks
docs.text:
• Set up a basic web server (Node.js/Python) and host a simple web page.
  • Implement a simple authentication mechanism in a web application.
  • Create a secure login system and compare HTTP vs HTTPS in handling sensitive data.
  • Use Wireshark to analyze HTTP and HTTPS traffic.

📖 Reference Articles: - How to Host a Web Server - Wireshark for HTTP Traffic Analysis

docs.title: Submission Guidelines
docs.text:
• Complete all tasks within the designated week while focusing on practical implementation.
  • Submit reports, summaries, and analyses, ensuring clarity and coherence.
  • Include screenshots and explanations where necessary.
  • Utilize free trials of AWS and Azure for cloud-based learning.

docs.title: Final Outcome
docs.text:
By completing this program, students will: ✅ Understand modern web applications, architectures, and protocols. ✅ Gain practical experience in web development and security analysis. ✅ Learn reconnaissance techniques and network analysis. ✅ Be familiar with best practices in web security and OWASP guidelines.
